Claim: People are lying on the ground in China because they contracted the coronavirus.
Explaination: Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite in a private school.
Label: False
html:
Claim: People are lying on the ground in China because they contracted the coronavirus.

Explanation:Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite in a private school.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200210-intox-video-coronavirus-chine-attention-afrique-sud

Claim: Patents mean deadly diseases and viruses were created or invented in a lab.
Explaination: Instead, the patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Patents mean deadly diseases and viruses were created or invented in a lab.

Explanation:Instead, the patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471816-fact-check-patents-do-not-mean-deadly-diseases-and-viruses-were-created-or-invented-in-a-lab.html

Claim: A post shows a rail freight tanker with “COVID-19” stamped on one side.
Explaination: The image has circulated globally but it is false, the tanker operating company said. And Railinc, a corporation that manages an industry-wide database, said there is no such mark as “COVID.”
Label: False
html:
Claim: A post shows a rail freight tanker with “COVID-19” stamped on one side.

Explanation:The image has circulated globally but it is false, the tanker operating company said. And Railinc, a corporation that manages an industry-wide database, said there is no such mark as “COVID.”

https://factcheck.afp.com/photo-covid-19-rail-tanker-not-genuine-0

Claim: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.

https://factcheck.afp.com/health-experts-refute-misleading-timeline-covid-19-symptoms

Claim: WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, in Ecuador.

Explanation:Please click the link to read the full article

http://www.ecuadorchequea.com/las-mentiras-sobre-el-covid-19-en-ecuador/

Claim: Pigs are being burned alive in China to control the coronavirus.
Explaination: Viral video is around a year old and has nothing to do with coronavirus in China.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Pigs are being burned alive in China to control the coronavirus.

Explanation:Viral video is around a year old and has nothing to do with coronavirus in China.

https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-is-the-chinese-govt-burning-pigs-alive-to-contain-coronavirus-1642960-2020-02-03

Claim: A video shows a man spitting inside food packets during the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The video is old and out of context, the man in the video blew on the plastic bag to open it up..
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video shows a man spitting inside food packets during the coronavirus crisis.

Explanation:The video is old and out of context, the man in the video blew on the plastic bag to open it up..

https://www.factcrescendo.com/fact-check-muslim-man-spitting-in-food-packet-viral-amidst-coronavirus/

Claim: A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:The claim is misleading; Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.

https://factcheck.afp.com/sri-lankan-authorities-say-medical-facilities-hospital-will-remain-open-all-covid-19-patients?check=1

Claim: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: The man in the viral video is former Malaysian Prime Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to China when he visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.

Explanation:The man in the viral video is former Malaysian Prime Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to China when he visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.

http://newsmobile.in/articles/2020/02/05/chinese-pm-didnt-visit-mosque-following-coronavirus-outbreak-heres-the-fact-check/

Claim: These charts show the difference betweem COVID-19, flu and common cold.
Explaination: Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms. They claim people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients, such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain, among others -- most of which can actually be seen among COVID-19 patients as well.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: These charts show the difference betweem COVID-19, flu and common cold.

Explanation:Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms. They claim people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients, such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain, among others -- most of which can actually be seen among COVID-19 patients as well.

https://medium.com/annie-lab/misleading-these-charts-about-covid-19-contain-inaccurate-medical-information-53ad9167ad3c

Claim: 10 coronavirus cases are confirmed in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False
html:
Claim: 10 coronavirus cases are confirmed in Ecuador.

Explanation:Please click the link to read the full article

Claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
Explaination: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.

Explanation:We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15307002

Claim: Thai department of health published an infographic on how to properly wear face masks.
Explaination: MOH denied.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Thai department of health published an infographic on how to properly wear face masks.

Explanation:MOH denied.

http://u.afp.com/ThaiFaceMasks

Claim: A viral video apparently showing Muslim devotees sneezing is circulated with the claim that it is from Nizamuddin mosque of Delhi and they are deliberately trying to get infected in order to spread coronavirus in India.
Explaination: The video shows an age-old Sufi ritual called Dhikr (Zikr). It is a kind of prayer/meditation in which followers of Sufism remember their god while breathing heavily. The video is available on the internet for the past few months. It has nothing to do with Nizamuddin Mosque or coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A viral video apparently showing Muslim devotees sneezing is circulated with the claim that it is from Nizamuddin mosque of Delhi and they are deliberately trying to get infected in order to spread coronavirus in India.

Explanation:The video shows an age-old Sufi ritual called Dhikr (Zikr). It is a kind of prayer/meditation in which followers of Sufism remember their god while breathing heavily. The video is available on the internet for the past few months. It has nothing to do with Nizamuddin Mosque or coronavirus.

https://marathi.factcrescendo.com/video-of-sufi-ritual-shared-with-false-claim-as-deliberate-attempt-of-spreading-coronavirus/

Claim: A video is going viral on WhatsApp and Sharechat claiming that the man and woman in the video are doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and now they both are infected by it.
Explaination: The claim associated with the video is false and misleading. They are not Italian doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and got infected but are actors from a Mexican television series called ‘Triunfo del Amor’.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video is going viral on WhatsApp and Sharechat claiming that the man and woman in the video are doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and now they both are infected by it.

Explanation:The claim associated with the video is false and misleading. They are not Italian doctors who treated 75 coronavirus patients and got infected but are actors from a Mexican television series called ‘Triunfo del Amor’.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15461976

Claim: Avoid ice-creams, cold drinks, and sweets for 90 days to prevent coronavirus.
Explaination: No scientific backing to say that the virus spreads through food items like ice creams and cold drinks. The virus has not even emerged in India.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Avoid ice-creams, cold drinks, and sweets for 90 days to prevent coronavirus.

Explanation:No scientific backing to say that the virus spreads through food items like ice creams and cold drinks. The virus has not even emerged in India.

https://www.boomlive.in/health/can-avoiding-ice-creams-and-cold-drinks-for-90-days-prevent-coronavirus-6689

Claim: Cow urine cures coronavirus.
Explaination: In our verification, we found several media reports, research reports, and advisories that talk about prevention and cure of the disease but there was no mention of cow urine and dung in these reports hence the claim made by the Hindu Mahasabha president Swami Chakrapani is ‘Misleading’.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Cow urine cures coronavirus.

Explanation:In our verification, we found several media reports, research reports, and advisories that talk about prevention and cure of the disease but there was no mention of cow urine and dung in these reports hence the claim made by the Hindu Mahasabha president Swami Chakrapani is ‘Misleading’.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_14743340

Claim: Muslim owned restaurants in Bengaluru have chefs brainwashed by Markaz attendees and are spreading Coronavirus by spitting in the food.
Explaination: The video is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing Nizamuddin Markaz controversy or Indian Muslim restaurant staff. Hence the claim is ‘Misleading’.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Muslim owned restaurants in Bengaluru have chefs brainwashed by Markaz attendees and are spreading Coronavirus by spitting in the food.

Explanation:The video is old and has nothing to do with the ongoing Nizamuddin Markaz controversy or Indian Muslim restaurant staff. Hence the claim is ‘Misleading’.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15553059

Claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.
Label: PANTS ON FIRE
html:
Claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”

Explanation:The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/feb/29/blog-posting/hair-extensions-arent-source-2019-coronavirus/

Claim: Scripps urgent care in San Diego is on lockdown, two people with the new coronavirus are isolated.
Explaination: Scripps denied it was true through their Twitter account, there was one person with the flu but no coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Scripps urgent care in San Diego is on lockdown, two people with the new coronavirus are isolated.

Explanation:Scripps denied it was true through their Twitter account, there was one person with the flu but no coronavirus.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471549-fake-news-scripps-urgent-care-not-on-lockdown-two-people-in-clinics-do-not-have-coronavirus.html

Claim: A video shows the effects of coronavirus and suggest people avoid ice cream and cold drinks for 90 days.
Explaination: Video shown in the viral post showing a person removing larvae from the lips using a pair of tweezers is old and unrelated to coronavirus. The claim in the viral post is also refuted by medical professionals.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video shows the effects of coronavirus and suggest people avoid ice cream and cold drinks for 90 days.

Explanation:Video shown in the viral post showing a person removing larvae from the lips using a pair of tweezers is old and unrelated to coronavirus. The claim in the viral post is also refuted by medical professionals.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-misinformation-related-to-coronavirus-outbreak-getting-viral/

Claim: NYT invented the video of a doctor fighting coronavirus in hospital.
Explaination: The video is real and Dr. Colleen Smith does work at the hospital, unlike the Tweet claims.
Label: False
html:
Claim: NYT invented the video of a doctor fighting coronavirus in hospital.

Explanation:The video is real and Dr. Colleen Smith does work at the hospital, unlike the Tweet claims.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/fact-check-nytimes-did-not-invent-doctor-fighting-coronavirus-in-qanon-conspiracy-theory.html

Claim: COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: A blog post claiming that the World Health Organization has announced COVID-19 as a vaccine against the novel coronavirus has a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:A blog post claiming that the World Health Organization has announced COVID-19 as a vaccine against the novel coronavirus has a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.

https://pesacheck.org/false-headline-covid-19-is-not-a-vaccine-against-novel-coronavirus-ef14477bb51a
